urn:contentItem:5XGG-46X1-DY0W-447S-00000-00The Proposed Australian Consumer Right to Access and Use Data:;A European Comparison2018-01-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:34:33ZLexisNexisPg. 187The Proposed Australian Consumer Right to Access and Use Data:A European ComparisonSamson Yoseph EsayasAngela DalyBerlinABSTRACT

This article examines the new Australian consumer Comprehensive right to access and use data, also known as the Consumer Data Right, recently proposed by the Australian Productivity Commission, and adopts a comparative analysis with data protection, competition and consumer developments in the European Union (EU). Firstly, a brief overview is given of the legal context and relevant Big Data developments in Australia. Then, current EU developments, particularly the data portability right under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), and recent proposals from the Commission aiming at fostering access and transfer of data including the data producer’s right to use and authorise the data and the portability of non-personal data for professional users are considered. This is followed by an explanation of the Australian Productivity Commission’s proposed Consumer Right to access and use data, before an analysis is conducted to understand the extent to which this proposed right accords with the European situation. Given the coming into force of the GDPR and its extraterritorial reach, and the EU-Australia Free Trade Agreement currently under negotiation, as well as the transnational reach of Big Data and Cloud services, standardisation across the two jurisdictions is desirable. In this regard, the article examines to what extent the recent initiatives contribute to such standardisation and their implications for the extent to which Australia’s legal framework for data may be considered ‘adequate’ by the EU. Keywords: Data Economy, Data Portability, Consumer Data Right, Data Access, GDPR

FULL TEXT

I. Introduction

The digital economy has involved large amounts of data being generated by and about individuals using online services and other technology products, with the archetypal example being users ‘paying’ for services which have no monetary cost with their data, which is the case with Facebook and Google for instance. This data is of great economic importance to digital services and products, which use it to profile users, modify their offerings, target advertising and sell on to third parties - practices which pose threats to individuals’ data protection and privacy rights from a fundamental rights perspective. Furthermore, individuals’ economic and consumer rights may also be negatively affected by these data gathering practices and uses, since individuals may find themselves ‘locked in’ to a particular service and unable to move their data to other services. This has potential consequences for competition in markets given the barriers to entry that this accumulation of data by players already operating in the market present to potential entrants, and the difficulty for consumers to switch between existing providers.1

In order to address some of these issues, the Australian Productivity Commission – an independent arms-length statutory public agency, which provides advice to the Australian Government on microeconomic policy, regulation and other social and environmental issues2 – issued a report in 2017 on Data Availability and Use, among whose recommendations was the introduction of a new ‘Comprehensive right to access and use digital data’ for consumers.3

This article examines this ‘Comprehensive right to access and use data’ proposed by the Productivity Commission, against developments in the European Union (EU) in the same field. Aside from the fact that both jurisdictions are considering the implementation of new measures to address some of the problems the digital economy presents for consumers, they are also both currently involved in free trade agreement negotiations, which may have implications for their respective regulations in this area, especially if there is currently divergence. Furthermore, with the EU’s General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) now in force, its extra-territorial effects may also have an impact on data practices in Australia. Therefore, a comparison of the two jurisdictions’ approaches so far is pertinent and timely. Before looking in more detail at the proposed Comprehensive right, some background context on Australia will now be given for a European audience.

II. Australian Context

Australia is a Western-style liberal democracy with a common law legal system, based to a large extent on English law. It has some similarities with the US since it has a written Constitution (based on the US Constitution) and is a federal system, with a federal-level, and state and territory-level jurisdictions. It continues to be influenced by legal developments in other common law jurisdictions, especially England and the US, but increasingly has looked to developments in the EU, particularly as regards regulatory issues including new technologies.

Australia has various laws which are relevant to the large accumulations of data currently being generated in the digital economy, with data protection, whose main legislative instrument is the Privacy Act 1988 (Cth), most prominent among them. Like the EU, Australia has consumer and competition laws which may apply to data issues. Unlike the EU, there is no equivalent in Australian intellectual property law to the rights contained in the Database Directive, either within copyright law or as sui generis rights.4

Broadly speaking, the Privacy Actis based on a similar model to the EU Data Protection Directive,5 although there are no constitutional protections for the right to privacy (or data protection for that matter) in Australian federal law. This is despite the fact that Australia is a signatory to international human rights treaties including the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) which includes the right to privacy.6 The Privacy Act applies to ‘personal information’, and governs the collection, use, storage and disclosure of this information, and also provides rights to access and correct this information for individuals. There are several divergences between the Privacy Act and EU data protection law, which is partly the reason Australia is not currently granted ‘adequacy’ status as a third country by the EU.7 These include: small and medium enterprises with an annual turnover of less than AUS$3 million being excluded from the Privacy Act’s obligations; various further broad exceptions and carve-outs from the Privacy Act’s obligations for law enforcement and security agency activities; Australia’s participation in the Five Eyes surveillance partnership; and the introduction of mandatory data retention legislation (after the EU’s Data Retention Directive was invalidated in Digital Rights Ireland).8 In addition, individuals do not have a direct means of enforcing their rights under the Privacy Act in courts, and instead must make a complaint to the federal Privacy Commissioner to investigate. However, there is concern that the federal Privacy Commissioner is under-resourced to perform this role properly.9 Furthermore, a tort of invasion of privacy is not currently recognised by Australian common law.10

As regards the governance of Big Data, as mentioned above, other areas of law such as competition and consumer law may apply. Yet in practice, Australia has been somewhat ‘behind’ other jurisdictions such as the EU, and to a lesser extent the US, especially as regards the application of competition law. To date, there has been no investigation opened by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) against Google analogous to those in the EU (and that concluded in the US) despite the fact that Google is likely to have a dominant position in the market(s) for online search and advertising in Australia.11 The reason why the ACCC has not opened such an investigation in unclear,12 although its current Inquiry into Digital Platforms (discussed in more detail below) may prove to be the initiation of some regulatory activity on this topic.

Some of the main legal proceedings involving Google in Australia to date were initiated by the ACCC on the basis of its role as the consumer regulator, in the Google v ACCC case,13 in which the ACCC alleged Google was engaging in misleading and deceptive conduct by allowing the competitors of trade mark owners to buy AdWords comprising the trade marked term, and then displaying adverts from those competitors when a consumer searched for the trade marked term.14 The High Court of Australia (the supreme court in the Australian court hierarchy and ultimate court of appeal) found that Google itself was not liable for misleading and deceptive conduct in the circumstances. Despite the outcome in this particular case – and despite the fact it concerned principally Google’s ‘front end’ search results pages rather than its vast ‘back end’ data collection, analysis and use – there is the potential for existing consumer law provisions to be utilised more to deal with data issues in the digital economy, in both Australia and the EU, in the form of its prohibitions both against misleading and deceptive conduct, and unfair terms in consumer contracts.15

While there may have been limited regulatory intervention thus far concerning data practices in Australian digital economy markets on the basis of data protection, consumer and competition law, there have been inquiries and proposals for reform. Prominently, in 2015 the Harper Review of Competition Policy recommended that the Government consider ways to improve individuals' ability to access their own data to inform consumer choices.16 The Productivity Commission’s proposed Consumer Right to Access and Use Digital Data is an attempt to put the Harper Review’s recommendation into practice. Furthermore, at the time of writing, the ACCC has opened an Inquiry into Digital Platforms:

The inquiry will look at the effect that digital search engines, social media platforms and other digital content aggregation platforms have on competition in media and advertising services markets. In particular, the inquiry will look at the impact of digital platforms on the supply of news and journalistic content and the implications of ­­this for media content creators, advertisers and consumers.17

An Issues Paper was released in February 2018. From the Issues Paper and the Terms of Reference, it appears that the Inquiry is framed as one examining in particular the impact of digital platforms such as Facebook and Google on the media and advertising industries, and consumers, from both competition and consumer law perspectives.18 The ACCC is scheduled to deliver a preliminary report on the topic in December 2018. The extent to which the Inquiry may deliver positive outcomes for consumers and their data, as opposed to incumbent media and advertising companies, remains to be seen.

III. European Context

In the last few years, the EU has also been exploring different ways to maximise the value of the enormous amount of digital data generated by consumers, sensors, and the Internet of Things (IoT) devices to individuals and the society at large while protecting the fundamental human rights of individuals. This has led to the adoption of different measures, starting with the 2012 reform package on data protection,19 the 2014 Communication ‘Towards a thriving data-driven economy’20 and the 2015 Digital Single Market Strategy for Europe,21 which partly culminated with the adoption of the GDPR on 27 April 2016.22 These initiatives are followed-up by the proposal for the ePrivacy Regulation,23 the 2017 Communication on ‘Building an EU Data Economy’,24 the proposed Regulation on Free Flow of Non-Personal Data25 and 2018 Communication ‘Towards a common European data space’.26 Although the measures across those initiatives are interlinked and are generally relevant for the Australian discussions, three aspects are of particular importance for the Comprehensive Right to access and use digital data. These are: the data portability right under Article 20 of the GDPR; and some of the proposed measures for ‘fostering data access and transfer’ under the Data Economy Communication such as the data producer’s right and the portability of non-personal data for professional users under the Proposed Regulation on Free Flow of Non-Personal Data. However, before delving into the analysis on the extent that the proposed Australian Right accords with the EU initiatives, a brief overview of the latter is provided.

1. Data Portability Right

At its core, data portability allows users of digital information services, such as Facebook, to transfer their data, eg photos, status updates, and videos, to another provider with ease. In the EU, it has been codified as a right under Article 20 of the GDPR, and is described as the ‘true innovation’ of the data protection law reform,27 which can be justified for two reasons. One is as an extension of an existing right to access one’s data and another is as a mechanism to deal with lock-in effects or high switching costs resulting from usage or technical difficulties that can prevent users from shifting to another service. The two components of the right to data portability under the GDPR cater to these two justifications.

The first component is the data subject’s right to obtain a copy of their personal data from the controller ‘in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format’.28 This aspect of the right is related to the data subject’s access rights and can facilitate the exercise or enforcement of other rights under the GDPR, eg, the data security principle (by giving users a backup copy), and the right to object to processing or erasure of data which is inaccurate or incomplete. The second component of the right enables the data subject to transmit or to have the data transmitted, where technically feasible, by the controller from one automated processing system to another one.29 This aspect of the right allows the data subject to take their personal data and leave (‘voting with one’s feet’). In this sense, the data portability right is partly driven by economic rationales, namely the desire to reduce switching costs between providers and thereby facilitate competition, including through privacy, among providers.30

The exercise of the data portability right is dependent on three conditions. The first precondition is that the data must be provided by data subjects themselves (volunteered data), although the Article 29 Working Party has opined that the right should extend to ‘observed data’.31 This means users will not have the possibility to port ‘inferred data’ and ‘derived data’, which include personal data that are created by a service provider (for example, algorithmic results).32 For example, a user of Facebook can only obtain data that they have posted to Facebook, not data posted by their Facebook friends or data that Facebook obtains from third party data brokers. Neither is the data that Facebook infers about users, such as their sexuality or political leanings,33 subject to this right. This makes the effective enforcement of such a right challenging without interoperability across platforms or services.34 The Commission seems to recognise this challenge and is undertaking initiatives to address this problem in the area of healthcare. With the aim of facilitating access and sharing of health data by users, the Commission is considering a mechanism for facilitating the interoperability of electronic health records, including a recommendation on a European exchange format for electronic health records.35

The second precondition is that, even when the data is provided by the data subject, the legal basis for processing should be based on either consent of the data subject or contract – meaning that processing based on legal obligations imposed on the controller or the vital interest of the data subject does not give rise to such an obligation. The third, perhaps redundant, precondition is that the right applies to a processing of personal data by ‘automated means’.36

Current implementations of the right seem to focus on the first component ie the right to obtain a copy of your data. For example, Facebook’s tool allows users to download a copy of their information either in HTML or JSON formats.37 The latter allows users to download their data in machine-readable format and users are able to transfer/upload the information to another service. Similarly, Google allows users to download their data either to their own computer, or to storage services like OneDrive, Dropbox and Box.38 However, the tools still fall short of allowing users to take their business elsewhere. This is because, under the current tools, service-to-service data transfers would require the user to download and re-upload it to another and expect the format is interoperable with the latter service. This notwithstanding, the big tech companies are joining forces to allow direct service-to-service data transfers. Recently, Facebook, Google, Twitter and Microsoft launched a joint initiative, the Data Transfer Project, with aim of facilitating direct transfer of data from one service to another.39 What makes the tool different from current technologies is that users do not need to ‘download and re-upload’.40 This reduces the reliance consumers’ potentially limited bandwidth and capability to transfer data from one service provider to another.41

It bears mentioning that the data portability right might raise concerns both for the data subject exercising the right or other data subjects. For example, in the absence of strict security requirements in exercising the right, moving all of a person’s data to another system ‘without hindrance’ creates security risks that can outweigh the portability benefits.42 This is the case where unintended privacy harms can occasion when consumers pull information in to less protected spaces and to providers with different policy and privacy norms. In this regard, the GDPR restricts the right to the extent it adversely affects ‘the rights and freedoms of others’.43 A case of such conflict might arise when the data portability right of a user impinges on other users’ right to be forgotten because the data of the users are inseparable and prevent the latter from having their data erased.44 In such cases, the right to erasure would override the right to data portability.45

2. Data Access and Transfer

Fostering access and transfer of data, particularly machine-generated data is one of the core objectives behind the recent Commission Communication on EU Data Economy.46 This need is justified for various reasons. The first is the unwillingness of many large data-generating organisations to share data with other entities. The Commission indicates that many companies that generate large sets of data do not share the data with third parties and thereby restricting its further use in other (downstream) markets.47 This is further complicated by the difficulty for users and customers of transferring their data from one provider to another provider. More particularly, the Commission notes that some manufacturers or service providers have become ‘de facto’ owners of the data despite the fact that the devices that generate the data are owned by the user, and thereby preventing users, through either technical measures (storage of data in proprietary formats) or imposing potentially unfair terms on the user, from sharing or transferring the data.48 These practices, together with the uncertainties on legal protection given to machine-generated data under the EU framework, are considered to hinder the further use of data for innovative services, to improve products or production processes and to support decision-making. The Commission then outlines different measures that could help address the problems with data access and transfer.

One such measure is to provide different incentives for sharing and transferring such data. Among other things, the Commission considers providing guidance on ‘how non-personal data control rights should be addressed in contracts.’49 This guidance might outline the transparency requirements in terms of how the data is used, including the fairness of terms in light of existing consumer protection laws and other protections under the Trade Secrets Directive and Database Directive. Part of this initiative is further taken up in the proposed Regulation on the Free Flow of Non-Personal Data, which is further elaborated below. More importantly, in its recent Communication, the Commission provides guiding principles for sharing of data between businesses (B2B).50 Key principles for B2B data sharing are: a) transparency, b) shared value creation,51 c) respect for each other’s commercial interests, d) ensure undistorted competition,52 and e) minimised data lock-in.53

The second measure that the Commission sees as facilitating access and transfer of machine-generated data is the development of technical measures that enable the reliable identification of the source of data that aim at increasing trust and benefit sharing.54 This requires fostering technical solutions that can trace and link the sources of the data so that the integrity of the data can be checked and benefits generated from the reuse of the data could be shared with the original sources.55 Such sharing of benefits is believed to increase the willingness to share and transfer data. This is a mechanism for implementing one of the above principles, ie, shared value creation.

The third consideration involves the use of default contract rules for sharing and transferring machine-generated data.56 The idea is that the Commission might come up with default contract terms for accessing and transferring such data and those default rules could serve as a benchmark for assessing the ‘fitness’ of other terms including in B2B relationships. This implies that the default rules could be used to invalidate contract terms that excessively deviate from such rules. A related consideration is to extend the application of the Unfair Contracts Directive,57 which currently applies to B2C contracts, to B2B relationships. The fourth is related to facilitating access of such data ‘for public interest and scientific purposes’.58 This recognizes the public interest in accessing the machine-generated data for statistical, environmental or traffic management purposes. In this regard, the recent Communication outlines the following guiding principles for the sharing of data between businesses and governments: a) proportionality in the use of private sector data, b) purpose limitation, c) do no harm, d) conditions for data re-use, e) mitigate limitations of private sector data, and f) transparency and societal participation.59 The accompanying Staff Working Document also discusses three models for data sharing, namely, an open data approach, data monetisation on a data marketplace and data exchange in a closed platform.60 Additionally, this Document provides a ‘How to’ guide on legal, business and technical aspects of data sharing’ between businesses.

The fifth, perhaps most ambitious project, is to recognize the data producer’s right to use and authorise the data.61 The data producer is the person or entity that owns or leases for long-term the devices that generate the data. This is to be contrasted with the data holder, which is the person or the entity that ‘manages and retains the machine-generated data in practice.’62 The aim of this right is to make it easier for the producer to utilise the data by providing the user more choices for generating value from the data. Among other things, this right aims at granting the producer an ‘exclusive right to utilise certain data, including the right to licence its usage.’63 This could be done by assigning a right in rem or de facto ‘possession’ right that is enforceable against third parties and regardless of contractual relationships including the right to prevent further use and claim damages for unauthorised use of the data.64 However, the Commission underlines the need to take account of the interest of the data holder, particularly in light of the investments in building the infrastructure, and interests of public authorities to access such data for public interest and scientific purposes.

The aforementioned right has raised many controversies in terms of its scope, impact on other rights and freedoms and its effectiveness.65 For example, there are claims that such a right creates multiple competing claims of ownership over data due to its significant overlap with pre-existing IP rights, the sui generis database right and trade secrets.66 Moreover, it can impinge on fundamental freedoms, particularly, freedom of expression and information by restricting, for instance, scientists’ access to data and freedom of competition.67 Others question the need for a new right as existing rights and rules, including IP and competition laws, already provide the necessary protection and incentives to share data.68

Another ambitious idea for facilitating access and transfer of data is to develop schemes for remuneration for sharing data.69 More particularly, the Commission in exploring the possibility of developing guiding principles for sharing of machine-generated data,70 particularly through the use of Fair, Reasonable and Non-Discriminatory (FRAND) terms for sharing data. 71 This scheme is currently used for sharing essential standard patents.

All of the above initiatives are accompanied by measures to respect individuals’ data privacy. The Communication underlines that if the machine-generated data to be shared is personal data, its sharing, be it with other third parties or with public authorities, should be done in compliance with the GDPR.72 In this regard, the Commission encourages the use of anonymisation techniques. Other measures include the need to establish different categories of data and adopting appropriate measures in light of each category before the data is being shared with other parties.73

3. Portability of Non-Personal Data

Another measure that aims at fostering access and transfer of data is the extension of the data portability right under the GDPR to non-personal data.74 This extension, which was initially articulated in the Commission Communication for EU Data Economy, is now encoded within the proposed Regulation on Free Flow of Non-Personal Data.75 The proposed Regulation recognizes the need to facilitate the portability of non-personal data by professional users.76 However, unlike the prescriptive nature of the data portability right under the GDPR, the Commission seems to prefer a light-touch regulatory approach that aims at creating an environment that facilitates the portability of non-personal data by professional users. Notably, the Commission undertakes to ‘encourage and facilitate the development of self-regulatory codes of conduct’ and best practices that facilitate switching of providers. In this regard, emphasis is given to measures that ensure transparency of the terms and conditions of service providers on data access and transfer. Accordingly, the codes of conduct should ensure that professional users are provided with ‘sufficiently detailed, clear and transparent information’ by the data storage or data processing service provider before the conclusion of the contract as regards the following issues:77

the processes, technical requirements, timeframes and charges that apply in case a professional user wants to switch to another provider or port data back to its own IT systems, including the processes and location of any data back-up, the available data formats and supports, the required IT configuration and minimum network bandwidth; the time required prior to initiating the porting process and the time during which the data will remain available for porting; and the guarantees for accessing data in the case of the bankruptcy of the provider; and

the operational requirements to switch or port data in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format allowing sufficient time for the user to switch or port the data.

Despite the initial enthusiasm to introduce portability rights for non-personal data under the Communication on an EU Data Economy, the approach adopted seems to focus on stimulating the market to respond to the challenges, rather than to prescribe how and when such portability should occur. The provision of this information is believed to increase competition among service provi­­ders on this aspect so that users can select their service provider based on such considerations of data access and transfer. However, given the dominance of few players in the data storage and processing services, the extent that such self-regulatory mechanisms would address the concerns raised by the Commission remains to be seen.78 This is particularly the case if noncompliance with the codes of conduct is not accompanied by some kind of sanction.

IV. The Proposed Australian Consumer Right to Access and Use Digital Data

The Australian Productivity Commission’s 2017 Data Availability and Use report was drafted as the outcome of an inquiry commissioned by the Australian Government to examine the ‘benefits and costs of options for increasing availability of and improving the use of public and private sector data by individuals and organisation’.79 The aim of this inquiry was for the Productivity Commission to recommend policies in this area for the Federal Government to consider that would ‘boost innovation and competition in Australia’.80

Among the Productivity Commission’s main findings was recognition of the exponential growth in data and its use in the digital economy which put existing data protection frameworks in need of reform, a process in which Australia was not yet participating.81 The Productivity Commission viewed that ‘marginal changes to existing structures and legislation will not suffice’, and it was necessary for data to be treated ‘as an asset and not a threat’.82 Among the ‘significant change needed for Australia’s open government agenda and the rights of consumers to data’ is the Productivity Commission’s recommendation of:

A new Comprehensive Right for consumers [which] would give individuals and small/medium businesses opportunities for active use of their own data and represent fundamental reform to Australia’s competition policy in a digital world. This right would create for consumers:

powers comparable to those in the Privacy Act to view, request edits or corrections, and be advised of the trade to third parties of consumer information held on them

a new right to have a machine-readable copy of their consumer data provided.83

The Comprehensive Right is intended as a counterpart to a new proposed risk-based structure for the sharing and release of both publicly- and privately-held datasets.84 The Comprehensive Right appears to be conceptualised by the Productivity Commission as being part of the ‘social licence’ which, by ostensibly empowering consumers to make better use of their data, they will also be more likely to support others using their data as well.85

The Productivity Commission acknowledges that currently Australians may have little control over how their data is used, and that the proposed Comprehensive Right would alter this by giving them such control which in turn ‘would enable them to have more influence in how value is created and extracted from their data’.86 The proposed reform is explicitly framed as one to competition law, and ‘not a subset of privacy law’ despite similarities in operation and in terms of the subject-matter of the right.87 The Productivity Commission, however, does acknowledge the existing rights consumers have to access data about themselves and correct that data, under privacy and freedom of information legislation but views these rights as being insufficient for consumer data use and access for various reasons, including a lack of understanding about what data is held about them and how to access it, a lack of meaningful consent to data being collected and used, and the lack of ease in authorising a third party to access a consumer’s data directly from the organisation which holds it.88

The Comprehensive Right would give consumers (defined as also including small and medium enterprises with an annual turnover of less than AU$3million, a narrower definition than under Australian consumer law) the right to:

access a copy of data

provided directly by the consumer or

collected in the course of other actions (and including administrative datasets) and identifiable to that consumer (whether aggregated or not) or

held by the data holder even though created by others — for example through screen-scraping or tracking, purchase of data about a consumer, or re-identification

request edits or corrections for reasons of accuracy

direct holders of such data to copy the data in machine-readable form, either to the consumer directly or to a nominated third party (the ‘transfer right’)

be informed about the trade of any element of this data to third parties

be advised of disclosures of data to third parties.89

The Right would apply to data held both by the public and private sectors. The scope of the data concerned would be broad and the Productivity Commission has suggested that it would cover digital data (and not paper-based data), which should be provided to the consumer in a machine-readable and interoperable format that is ‘held by a product or service provider and identified with a consumer and associated with a product or service provided to that consumer’. It would seem that the Productivity Commission intends for this definition to encapsulate a broader range of data than ‘personal information’ which is currently covered by Australian federal data protection law in the form of the Privacy Act:90

Consumer data for this Right should be defined broadly and with a focus on desired outcomes, but with an opportunity for inclusion of data that is merely imputed to be about the consumer.91

However, the application of the definition of ‘personal information’ in Australian law is currently unclear, despite recent litigation on the topic.92 The Productivity Commission, though, does recommend the development of sector-specific definitions of consumer data by industry participants, which may vary from sector to sector. Data which is collected for security purposes or subject to intellectual property rights would be excluded from the definition of consumer data.

The Productivity Commission decided to withdraw some suggestions it made in its previous Draft Report on the topic, including a right for consumers to request that a data holder stop collecting information on them (due to ‘inadvertent consequences and be[ing] difficult to implement’) and a right to appeal automated decisions similar to the right to explanation in Article 22(1) of the GDPR (since consumers should be able to query the data on which the decision, automated or not, was based, and would already have a right to request corrections to incorrect data under the Comprehensive Right).93

Exceptions to the Comprehensive Right may be broadly based on those currently in existence as regards access to personal information in the Privacy Act, and may include ‘when giving access would prejudice current legal proceedings, be contrary to another law, or reveal information in conjunction with a commercially sensitive decision making process’.94

In terms of governance and enforcement of this Comprehensive Right, the Productivity Commission viewed that compliance should be driven by the ACCC ‘since competition and consumer policy lies at the heart of the recommended changes’.95 This model is also contrasted against what the Productivity Commission sees as the ‘American’ approach where individuals are granted rights to sue organisations breaching their rights, in order to enforce those rights directly.96

The Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) is not viewed to have an active role in enforcing the Comprehensive Right, despite the proximity of the Comprehensive right to data privacy rights, whose enforcement falls within the OAIC’s portfolio as federal Privacy Commissioner. Furthermore, the Productivity Commission emphatically recommends that the Comprehensive Data Right be implemented as part of entirely new legislation (‘Data Sharing and Release Act’) rather than as an amendment to the existing Privacy Act.97 The Productivity Commission seemed to find the ‘human rights’ framing of privacy as unhelpful for what it is trying to achieve with the Comprehensive Data Rights, since it saw a human rights lens as being ‘unlikely to see cultural change’ because ‘it encourages data to be viewed as a risk rather than an asset’.

V. Comparative Analysis

In the following paragraphs, we provide a comparison of the new Comprehensive Right proposed in the Australian Productivity Commission’s report in light of the above three EU developments. This is followed by a discussion on the convergences between the EU and Australian data frameworks from these initiatives and their implications for Australia’s adequacy assessment and the forthcoming EU-Australia free trade agreement negotiations given a potential agreement may include digital economy matters.98

In light of the above discussions, the Comprehensive Right seems to contain a bundle of features from the data portability right under the GDPR, the Commission initiatives to foster data access and transfer and the portability of non-personal data. It is similar to the GDPR’s data portability right because it allows consumers to port their personal data as defined by the Privacy Act. But it is broader than the data portability right under the GDPR because,99 first, the new right covers data that is not strictly personal and there are no requirements for the data to be provided by the consumer.100 The Comprehensive Right would apply to any data that can be ‘identified with a consumer and associated with a product or service provided to that consumer’, which may well extend beyond ‘personal information’ or ‘personal data’ to include items such as electronic consumption data and documents stored in cloud service provider. However, the Comprehensive Right might not extend to digital content purchased by a consumer given this is likely to be protected by IP which the Productivity Commission viewed as being a potential exception to the Comprehensive Right.

Secondly, unlike the GDPR’s data portability right which only applies to data collected on the basis of consent or for the performance of a contract, the Australian Comprehensive Right would apply regardless of the basis for the initial data collection. Moreover, as mentioned above, the term ‘consumer’ would be defined broadly to include SMEs with ‘a turnover of less than AU$3m pa in the most recent financial year.’101 This entails that data that can be linked to these SMEs would be subject to the Comprehensive Right requirements whereas the EU’s data portability right applies to data that can be linked to a natural person.102

In this regard, the Comprehensive Right is similar to the portability of non-personal data under the EU’s proposed Regulation for Free Flow of Data as it covers data that relates to businesses. However, unlike the portability of non-personal data under the proposed EU Regulation, the Comprehensive Right imposes a maximum turnover-based restriction. Against this background, the portability initiative under the EU Regulation applies only to non-personal data, meaning that it does not apply to the portability of personal data by professional users (except where the user is a data subject, in which case they can rely on the GDPR). This is perhaps one of the weaknesses of the EU initiative because professional users including SMEs face similar challenges with transferring personal data stored with cloud service providers as with non-personal data. Thus, there is no good reason why such professional users should not be allowed to transfer personal data between cloud services providers. It is also doubtful if data privacy concerns justify such an exclusion because the ease of transfer or portability could actually contribute positively to protection of data privacy. Knowledge of the technical requirements for transferring to or retrieving data from their own systems, location of data back-up and bandwidths for access data are relevant for a data controller to ensure compliance with its obligations under the GDPR including the data security requirements and the rules on international transfer of data. It can also facilitate data controllers switching to providers that offer greater security and better access.103 However, given the proposed solution focuses on stimulating the market to be transparent on the conditions of access and transfer, it can be expected that to the extent the proposal bears fruit, it will bring changes across the board including for access and transfer personal data stored with cloud service providers.

In contrast, the Comprehensive Right would cover both ‘personal information’ as defined under the Australian Privacy Act and data that is otherwise imputable to a consumer, including a legal person in the form of an SME. In this sense, the Comprehensive Right would be broader in reach than both the GDPR’s data portability right and the portability of non-personal data under the proposed Regulation for Free flow of Data (with the only exception being that the latter does not have a turnover-based restriction). However, there are several other EU instruments that allow consumers and competitors to access and sometimes port different kinds of data. For example, the Payment Service Directive 2,104 which is effective as of 13 January 2018, has a provision that allows consumers but also entities, to access bank and transaction information. Similarly, the Internal Electricity Market Directive aims at improving consumers’ access to their smart meter data.105 The Commission has also tabled a proposal that allows third party providers to request access to such data with the consumers’ consent.106 Furthermore, the proposed Directive on Digital Content has a provision that gives consumers the right to retrieve their data from providers.107 The Gas and Electricity Directives allow industrial customers right to access and transfer data. Regulation 715/2007 facilitates access to in-vehicle data for the purpose of after-market services such as maintenance and repair.108 In combination, these sector-specific requirements may bring the EU framework closer to the Comprehensive Right, although they still suffer from fragmentation and a lack of cross-sector harmonisation.

Last but not least, the Comprehensive Right has similar objectives to the EU Commission initiatives that aim at fostering data access and transfer. It is particularly similar to the data producer’s proposed right ‘to utilise certain data, including the right to licence its usage.’109 As noted above, the Comprehensive Right has a similar objective of providing ‘a social licence for wider data use, both public and private.’110 Both initiatives recognize the need to consider competing interests in the enforcement of the rights. For example, the European Commission initiative on the data producer’s right to use and authorise data recognises the need to take account of the interest of the data holder, particularly in light of the investments in building the infrastructure, and interests of public authorities to access such data for public interest and scientific purposes. Similarly, the report from the Productivity Commission underlines that ‘Consumer data would be a joint asset between the individual consumer and the entity holding the data. Exercise of the right by a consumer would not alter the ability of the initial data holder to retain and keep using the data.’111 Both initiatives are expected to increase competition and the value generated from digital data. However, the discussions on the data producer’s right are limited to machine-generated non-personal data whereas the Comprehensive Right applies broadly to digital consumer data.

Apart from the Comprehensive Right, the report from the Productivity Commission contains several other initiatives that aim at facilitating data sharing and access. These include the establishment of Accredited Release Authorities (ARAs) that would oversee and administer a risk-based framework for sharing and releasing data both by private and private entities.112 The report also considers the designation of certain databases as National Interest Datasets (NID) based on their value, uniqueness and quality (up-to-date, coverage).113 The ARAs would be mandated to ensure that such databases are widely available for private and public uses. These are initiatives that have similar objectives with the EU Commission’s measures aimed at fostering access and transfer of data by different incentives for sharing and transferring such data, encouraging the development of technical measures that enable the reliable identification of the source of data and enacting default contract rules for sharing and transferring machine-generated data.

From a broader policy perspective, the initiatives in the EU and Australia demonstrate the willingness to maximise the value of data for individuals and for society at large. Similarly, the reliance on light touch regulatory approaches to facilitate the access and transfer of data is common to both jurisdictions although the Australian proposals seem to be backed by a stick in the form of the ACCC intervening in case the relevant stakeholder fails to act. However, there seems to be a significant difference in the level of attention given to the privacy of individuals. For example, the initiatives from the Commission including the data producer’s right to use and authorise data, access based on FRAND terms as well as the portability of data apply to anonymised data or data that is non-personal. None of these initiatives aim at adding new exceptions to the application of the GDPR. Where personal data is involved both the Communication and the Staff Working Document make it clear that access and use of such data should be subject to the GDPR and ePrivacy Directive.

While the Productivity Commission’s report also recognizes the importance of the right to privacy and the need to respect existing privacy legislation,114 it advocates further exceptions from obligations under the Privacy Act. More particularly, the proposal seeks to extend some of these exceptions ‘allowing the sharing of personal information for health and medical research purposes without consent … to other areas of public interest research.’115 It also recommends the abolishment of the ‘requirement to destroy linked datasets and statistical linkage keys at the completion of data integration projects’, comparing hyperbolically such actions to ‘book burning.’116 Given that the exceptions for SMEs under the Privacy Actare part of the reason that Australia has not yet received the approval as a country that ensures ‘adequate protection’ under the EU Data Protection Directive, the potential to further expand these exceptions and carve-outs from the Privacy Act’s protections would further weaken the case for Australia’s ‘adequacy’ from an EU data protection perspective, in addition to other divergences from the GDPR. This scenario may be problematic for Australian entities handling EU citizens’ data in scenarios which fall within Article 3(2) of the GDPR, as they may have to comply with both EU and Australian requirements concerning this data. Furthermore, any regulatory divergence may have to be overcome for the successful conclusion of an EU-Australia FTA if such an agreement is to include digital economy issues.

VI. Conclusion

This article has offered a preliminary analysis of the Australian Productivity Commission’s proposed Comprehensive Consumer Right to Access and Use Digital Data, and a comparison with similar initiatives in the European Union. Overall, both jurisdictions are seeking to facilitate greater access to data for consumers, driven by competition goals, to enable consumers to port their data between providers, with the hope of stimulating competition in digital markets. The jurisdictions diverge in certain ways, including the potential increased scope of the proposed Comprehensive Right compared to the GDPR’s right to data portability, and the framing of the Comprehensive Right as a consumer or competition law measure as opposed to a data protection measure, while a similar right is contained within the EU’s main data protection legislation and backed by the legal system’s recognition of both privacy and data protection as fundamental rights. Another main divergence is the fact that the proposed Comprehensive Right remains a mere proposal rather than binding law, in contrast to the binding nature of the GDPR’s right to data portability.

However, in late 2017, the Australian Government announced that it would introduce a Bill into the Australian Parliament during 2018 to implement a ‘Consumer Data Right’ into legislation.117 More recently, the Australian Government confirmed this plan in its official response to the Productivity Commission report, where it also stated that the right would be implemented first in the banking,118 energy and telecommunications sectors, and that, in contrast to the Productivity Commission’s suggestions, the OAIC would have primary responsibility for individual consumer complaints (with the ACCC’s role being at a more macro level, in ‘supporting competition and good consumer outcomes’) and the right would be introduced primarily through amendments to Competition and Consumer Act 2010 (Cth).119

Yet, these measures, both implemented and proposed, in Australia and the EU for consumer data rights for the purposes of facilitating switching between providers, raise questions about how efficacious such rights actually are. There is very limited empirical research on the extent to which consumers make use of existing data rights they have regarding providers in some sectors, the extent to which this facilitates competition in practice, and the interplay with data protection frameworks. These rights, both existing and proposed, tend to implicate an idea of consumers who are pro-active about using and allowing others to use their data, and also, at a more abstract level, imagines data to be an asset rather than a fundamental right to be protected.120 Data has a hybrid character, at least in the EU, where it is recognised to have economic as well as a fundamental rights aspects.121 The Australian Productivity Commission’s approach privileges this economic character over the fundamental rights character in its proposal for the Comprehensive Consumer Right. Given recent deficiencies with Australia’s protection of data privacy, more account should be taken of data’s dual character in any legislation introduced to the Australian Parliament to implement such a right.122 The Australian Government’s recent response does emphasise the need for the Consumer Data Right to be designed ‘to ensure strong privacy protections and security safeguards’. The implementation of the Consumer Data Rights ought to involve higher standards of data protection and security provisions and practices than is currently the case.

In the financial sector implementation of the Consumer Data Right via ‘Open Banking’, it does seem that more regard is being paid to privacy and data protection concerns.123 The Australian Treasury has stated that consumers must give explicit, informed consent to data transfers and implied consent will not be permitted.124 The Treasury also enumerated other specific ways in which privacy protections will be strengthened in the Right’s implementation in banking, including the extension of Privacy Act protections to all accredited data recipients including SMEs which would not otherwise be bound by the provisions, and direct rights of action for consumers in the case of breaches.125 The existence of a direct right of action is a major development from the Privacy Act scenario as mentioned earlier, where individuals are not able to bring an action themselves against a party in breach of their rights, and thus is an important step towards the better protection of fundamental rights in Australia.

However, the Consumer Data Right – which should perhaps be better termed ‘the Consumer Data Portability Right’ – is only a singular intervention in Australian law concerning data. Australian law needs a much more comprehensive overhaul to ensure better fundamental rights compliance – and ‘adequacy’ from an EU data protection law perspective – which the Consumer Data Right will not bring about alone.

Postscript

As this article was going to press, the Australian Treasury released the exposure draft legislation for the Consumer Data Right, the Treasury Laws Amendment (Consumer Data Right) Bill 2018, which contains proposed amendments principally to the Competition and Consumer Act 2010, but also the Privacy Act 1988 and the Australian Information Commissioner Act 2010.

A cursory glance at this Bill reveals that details of the Consumer Data Right’s operation would be determined sector-by-sector through ‘Consumer Data Rules’ overseen by the ACCC, with the Consumer Data Right planned to be implemented initially in the banking sector. The Treasurer would be responsible for designating further sectors to which the right should apply. Before entities in a particular sector can receive transfers of consumer data, they should be ‘accredited’ by the ACCC (subject to some exceptions), with part of the accreditation process being adherence to privacy and security safeguards. These safeguards are considered by the Treasury to exceed those currently contained in the Privacy Act’s Australian Privacy Principles, would apply to a broader range of data than ‘personal information’ and would also apply to SMEs which gain accreditation but which would not be subject to the Privacy Act.

These proposals suggest a definitive shift away from the Productivity Commission’s privacy-unfriendly position to one that takes privacy issues far more seriously, and in fact seems to offer a higher level of protection than the existing Privacy Act. It remains to be seen whether this Bill becomes law, and if so, to what extent it may be amended from this initial form. However, the greater regard paid to privacy here is to be welcomed, and - while a full assessment is beyond the scope of this postscript, and in fact should form the basis of further research - may result in Australia providing an ‘adequate’ level of data protection by EU standards, at least as regards data portability.

urn:contentItem:5TM3-1C51-JCMN-Y3VY-00000-00The 'pseudo Google tax' which could finally see Facebook and Amazon pay their fair share2018-10-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:34:32ZLexisNexisThe 'pseudo Google tax' which could finally see Facebook and Amazon pay their fair shareProactiveinvestors

Oct 30, 2018( Proactive Investors: http://www.proactiveinvestors.com Delivered by Newstex) As part of Monday's Budget speech, Chancellor Philip Hammond unveiled his highly-anticipated digital sales tax, which some commentators have referred to as a 'pseudo Google tax'. At the moment, tech companies such as Facebook, Google and Amazon.com are taxed on how much profit they make in the UK, but campaigners have often accused them of artificially reducing their profits so they can pay less tax. READ: The Budget as it happened Instead, the Chancellor wants to tax their revenues, a much larger figure which is harder to manipulate. Taxing anything other than profits is virtually unheard of, so the UK will be a pioneer of this model, with the international community, which is similarly frustrated by the lack of tax paid by the big tech firms, looking on closely.

His plan is to hit 'established tech giants' - those which are profitable and generate global revenues of at least 500mln a year - with a 2% tax on all sales that they make in the UK. Addressing Parliament, Hammond said: 'It is clearly not sustainable or fair that digital platform businesses can generate substantial value in the UK without paying tax here.' For example, Amazon paid 4.5mln in taxes to the UK government last year despite turning over almost 2bn. Under the new proposals, it would have to pay HMRC 40mln. Blue-chips targeted, not start-ups Markets.com analyst Neil Wilson said the hike was 'not entirely immaterial' for the firms but also 'not really that meaningful' either. The UK is well-known for its thriving digital start-up community, particularly those in the fintech sector, and Hammond was at pains to reassure them that it would be the bigger players who 'shoulder the burden' of the new levy. 'The [500mln] threshold means this tax is aimed squarely at the likes of Facebook, Alphabet, Amazon and maybe a couple others,' Wilson noted. Assuming Parliament votes through the proposal - corporate tax is an issue which has attracted cross-party ire - the changes would come in to force in April 2020. For the 2019-20 tax year, the treasury has estimated that the tax will bring in an additional 275mln before gradually rising up to 440mln in 2022-23. Other governments to follow suit? 'A tax take of 400mln or so might seem a small number when you consider that Amazon alone is expected to post sales of US$233bn this year,' said Hargreaves Lansdown analyst Laith Khalaf. 'But the worry for the tech giants, and their shareholders, is that this is the pebble that starts an avalanche of taxes from international governments.' Both the 36-member Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and the European Commission have been trying to agree how to tax social media platforms, internet marketplaces and search engines. They haven't had much joy in reaching a consensus yet, with Hammond describing progress as 'painfully slow', hence why he's decided to go it alone for the time being. The UK government has earmarked April 2020 as the likely start date for its regulations, although by that point, the Chancellor hopes that a global agreement on digital turnover tax will have been agreed.

urn:contentItem:5Y67-GRW1-JC8J-R168-00000-00THE PSYCHOLOGY OF SILICON VALLEY;Ethical Threats and Emotional Unintelligence in the Tech Industry2020-02-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:34:33ZLexisNexisNONFICTIONTechnologyTHE PSYCHOLOGY OF SILICON VALLEYEthical Threats and Emotional Unintelligence in the Tech Industry

A well-researched evaluation of how the tech industry represents itself as a panacea for all the world's problems. In the mid-1960s, William Cannon and Dallis Perry, two psychologists, decided the "two key profile characteristics" of computer programmers were "an interest in solving puzzles and a dislike of or disinterest in people." And so, a stereotype was born.

Cook, who holds a doctorate in clinical, educational, and health psychology from University College London, traces Silicon Valley's current dysfunctions to its early valorization of logic over social awareness and of analytical skill over emotional intelligence. A fundamental lack of empathy in the tech sector, Cook argues, has allowed Silicon Valley's most influential players to hoard consumer data and repurpose it as fuel for their hypercapitalist profit machines. Various social problems, she says, can be linked to this economic arrangement, including job displacement, a loneliness epidemic, diminishing privacy rights, housing shortages in the San Francisco area, political polarization, and the controversial Brexit campaign in the United Kingdom. This unique psychology-based approach to the digital economy is a valuable, scholarly achievement. Many other authors have made these same connections over the past few years, but Cook offers a meticulously well-sourced compilation of these critiques. Big tech has held tightly to a prosocial self-conception-so much so, Cook notes, that Facebook's "move fast and break things" motto takes on a new interpretation: "Moving fast and breaking things in the name of growth has been accomplished to startling effect; unfortunately, what has been broken are communities, trust, and informed discussion, along with the evolution of a new brand of tribalism, which spreads more easily and is more difficult to immobilize." Ultimately, the author calls for increased regulation, systemic changes, and "values reformation." Scholarship, timeliness, and an informed psychological perspective set this book apart from other Silicon Valley critiques.

urn:contentItem:5YX4-3SX1-JCBF-S53R-00000-00THE PUBLIC HEALTH EMERGENCY PRIVACY ACT PUTS IN PLACE SAFEGUARDS FOR DIGITAL CONTACT TRACING2020-05-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:34:33ZLexisNexisTHE PUBLIC HEALTH EMERGENCY PRIVACY ACT PUTS IN PLACE SAFEGUARDS FOR DIGITAL CONTACT TRACINGStates News ServiceWASHINGTON, DC

The following information was released by Free Press:

On Thursday, Reps. Anna Eshoo (DCalifornia), Zoe Lofgren (DCalifornia) and Suzan DelBene (DWashington) joined Sens. Richard Blumenthal (DConnecticut) and Mark Warner (DVirginia) to introduce a privacy bill addressing the use of technology to track the spread of COVID-19 during the pandemic.

The Public Health Emergency Privacy Act (PHEPA) provides needed regulations on exposure-notification and contact-tracing applications whether built and deployed by state and local governments or by tech companies and other private-sector employers. These protections mandate that the use of these digital tools be voluntary; that information collected such as medical diagnoses and exam data, and location or proximity information be limited to what's necessary and proportionate to addressing the public-health crisis.

The bill bans commercial use of that information, and protects the civil rights of people who use these applications by preventing discrimination in access to public-facing businesses like stores, and other commercial establishments and public spaces, based on whether a person uses such an application or not.

Free Press Action Senior Policy Counsel Gaurav Laroia made the following statement:

"There's an understandable desire to use state-of-the-art technology to combat the spread of COVID-19. Some of these technologies may prove effective in addressing this public-health emergency, but efforts to contain coronavirus shouldn't open the door to a more abusive and discriminatory surveillance system.

"Governments and businesses across the world have begun deploying digital technology to trace people's movements and contacts to help stop the spread of the disease. Almost all of that information collection and tracking is unregulated here in the United States, opening the door to potential abuses. This bill would put many necessary protections in place to make sure the technology is used responsibly.

"This bill makes it clear that we don't need to completely sacrifice privacy, data protection and civil rights to make these tools effective. And for them to work, a large majority of cellphone users would need to use them. Without PHEPA's protections to secure this information, people will be reluctant to use contact-tracing applications in the numbers needed to make the technology useful.

"Unlike the proposal put forth by Senator Wicker and other Senate Republicans, PHEPA also protects workers from undue and unnecessary surveillance. Black and Latinx essential workers are bearing the brunt of this crisis while dying in disproportionate numbers. Digital tools may help keep them safe, but employers' use of these tools must be regulated. This crisis cannot turn already difficult working conditions into a pretext to deploy long-lasting and unnecessary worker surveillance.

"If we've learned anything from experience with widespread data collection it's that stringent safeguards and oversight are necessary to prevent personal data from falling into the hands of those who seek to misuse it. The bill rightfully tightly ties this data collection to solving the public-health crisis and prevents using that information for commercial purposes. The bill also prohibits the unnecessary sharing of that data with law-enforcement agencies which would undermine the goal of widespread adoption, especially among the most vulnerable.

"We've seen big tech companies mishandle data they collect from their users, exploiting it for purposes other than those they officially claim. Their promises to protect our essential information aren't enough. We need policies to limit data collection at its source, with clear restrictions and rules on what's being gathered, by whom, how it's being stored, how it gets used and for how long. PHEPA puts many of these vital safeguards in place."

urn:contentItem:5Y2V-S3W1-JCRW-52XT-00000-00The punitive approach to U.S. data privacy regulation will backfire2020-01-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:34:33ZLexisNexisThe punitive approach to U.S. data privacy regulation will backfireRon Rock

Unlike Vegas, what happens in California will not stay in California. Just ask anyone trying to sell automobiles in the United States.

On January 1, 2020, the new (CCPA) went into effect with consequences felt far beyond the state's borders. This has lit a fire under Congress, where proposals for data regulation appear aimed more at punishing misconduct and negligence by Big Tech than at creating a data ecosystem that properly balances privacy, security, commerce and innovation.

This is a shame. Designing such far-reaching legislation in the current atmosphere of fear and anger - not to mention during a U.S. election year - is a mistake. The result will be a punitive system that threatens huge fines for perceived violations of a somewhat difficult to interpret regulation, one that frankly doesn't add much to the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) law that has already forced global digital players to comply.

Worse still, it will stifle innovation without achieving its main goal: bringing greater security and privacy protections to the American public. The legalistic regulatory approach enacted in Sacramento and now contemplated in Washington, too, will simply spawn an ocean of legalistic disclaimers and opt-outs (along with the legal fees required to produce them) and launch a hunt by players small and large for the loopholes that invariably exist when laws are passed to win political points rather than after long, nonpartisan study aimed at finding optimal solutions.

Golden Opportunity

That California would be the beachhead for the regulatory campaign that began with the May 2018 enactment of GDPR in Europe is hardly surprising. Back in 2007, California's decision to set higher fuel efficiency standards than the rest of the US forced the rest of the world - not just US automakers, but foreign manufacturers, too, eager to sell cars in the United States - to scramble.

The powerful auto and energy lobbies tried to kill the move, but the Golden State's higher bar was affirmed by EPA in 2009 when it issued an exemption allow the state to exceed federal standards. That the Trump administration recently revoked this exemption matters little. It takes time and a lot of money to change production lines and auto designs, whether the change is meant to raise or lower fuel efficiency. As a result, the effects of California's higher standards are very likely to outlive the current administration.

This scenario is now playing out on data regulation. GDPR was the first shot: By dint of the EU's size, its new regulatory approach invariably forced compliance on many firms outside its borders. In simpler times, the EU's enactment of GDPR would have spurred trans-Atlantic talks to harmonize the legal codes of the world's two largest economic entities. But these are not simple times when it comes to data.

As readers of this site know by now, GDPR levies fines of up to 4% of annual revenue on companies doing business in Europe who fail to protect the personal data and privacy of EU citizens. This so far has cost companies over $100 million in legal and other fees, according to the European Parliament's data protection registry, including the rewiring of digital business plans and platforms, the hiring of "Chief Data Officers," a relatively new post necessitated by the law, and other compliance measures. Google was hit quickly with a $57 million fine in 2018. In September 2019, British Airways took the dubious crown for the largest fine to date at $228 million.

California's state legislators, once incredibly pliant when it came to technology regulation due to the power of Silicon Valley lobbyists, have since 2016 joined the bandwagon of tech bashers - a vote-winning caravan in a largely Democratic state since the 2016 Facebook-Russia election fiasco. And as with the EU, it's size matters. California is not only the largest internal market in the US, but if it were a nation, its $2.9 trillion 2018 GDP would make it the fifth largest economy in the world, slotting in right between Germany (No. 4) and the UK (No. 6).

Rumblings back East

The confluence of data paranoia and California's history as a state that can make national policy will ensure that Congress, a notoriously Luddite institution, will now act. Suddenly, less than a month before the US presidential primary season begins, a rare bipartisan push towards federal data protection legislation has emerged aimed at forestalling a state-by-state patchwork and, for the GOP at least, denying vindication to reviled activist legislators of California.

Was a nonpartisan panel of experts convened? Has Congress examined the many proposals for digital sovereignty or third-party data protocols - including the one ? No. They held televised star chamber hearings to eviscerate the CEOs of the major technology firms without demonstrating much knowledge of the complexities involved. Did Facebook deserve its drubbing? Probably. Is the laissez faire approach that dominated the first two decades of the digital revolution in need of guardrails? Absolutely.

Now Congress is moving forward with a sledgehammer where an architect's fine pencil is more appropriate. In November, Sen. Maria Cantwell, D-WA and the top Democrat on the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee, introduced a new national privacy bill - , - aimed at providing consumers with digital "Miranda rights" and impose tough penalties on companies that abuse consumer data.

So Republicans, eager to find some compromise that would prevent a patchwork of state laws like the CCPA from being enforced, have made . It dials back some of the disclosure requirements of Cantwell's bill, and also would preempt state data laws, a provision that would deny California the satisfaction of again setting national policy.

Everything in Moderation

I don't deny the downside risks or the need for standards. I could list the big hacks and point to outrages regarding personal privacy, but you know that story. All new technologies come with downside risk. Wheels, a seminal human invention, not only move things but also crushed us to death now and then. The printing press brought literacy and ideas to medieval civilization but also Mein Kampf and child pornography. Aircraft made the planet smaller but also dropped jellied petroleum on Dresden and atomic weapons on Nagasaki and Hiroshima.

We didn't ban wheels, printing presses or aircraft. The harnessing, sharing and selling of data will displace workers, prove invasive in some forms, and may well be turning our children into little Zombies. But humans manage risk and adapt to change: that's what we do. We will survive the challenges of the technology age, too.

For all the downside risks involved in the transfer and collection of data, I believe the upside is greater by far. Data on our health and nutrition will extend our lives; Data has the potential to eliminate traffic accidents. Data will make everything from buildings to ships to hospitals more sustainable and more efficient. Even inequality can be tackled: Data gleaned from mobile payments systems in the far reaches of the developing world shunned by traditional finance - from sub-Saharan Africa to the Andes to Southeast Asia - are enabling small farmers, merchants and village craftsmen to access small loans and insurance based on risk calculations drawn from shared data.

The data debate is complex.
